quote: You wound me, Mon Capitain. After all, I wasn't the cause of your death...
... this was.
Is that...
Your artificial heart.
You might have lived if you'd had a real heart instead of this unreliable piece of technology. How did you manage to lose yours anyway?
It was a... mistake.
Something you regret?
I regret a great many things from those days...
Really?
It wasn't very smart of you to take on three Nausicaans like that.
No, it wasn't.
And did I hear you laugh? It's so unlike you to have a sense of humor... especially about getting stabbed through the back.
I was... a different person in those days... an arrogant, undisciplined, young man with far too much ego and far too little wisdom. I was more like you.
I'm sure you were far more interesting in those days. A pity you had to change.
The only pity is that I had to be impaled through the back before I learned my lesson. I started that fight with the Nausicaans... I started it because I was young and cocky...
If I had been more responsible at that age... I wouldn't have needed this heart... and I wouldn't have died from a random energy surge thirty years later.
So if you had it to do all over again... ?
Things would be different...
Bravo! Bravo!
Nicely done.
Cortan? Cortan Zweller?
Of course it's me... boy, she must've hit you pretty hard.
You're slowing down, Johnny. You should've seen that one coming.
Marta...
Are you okay?
I'm... just a little disoriented...
Oh, please. Now he's just playing for sympathy.
I want to get something to eat and head over to the casino at Bonestell. Who's coming?
I'll... catch up with you later.
Are you sure you're all right?
No, no. I'm fine Marta -- Marty, really.
Come on, Marty. I bet he has another date anyway.
That's it, isn't it? You are incorrigible.
Try not to end up in the hospital.
Attention on deck, Ensign Picard!
That's Captain Q to you, young man.
What's the point of creating this... fantasy?
It's no fantasy. This is all very real, I assure you. You're twenty-one years old again... a brash young man, fresh out of the Academy.
I don't look it.
To everyone else, you do.
I thought you said I was dead... now you tell me I'm alive?
You mortals can be so obtuse. Why do you persist in believing that life and death are such static and rigid concepts.
I can take your life and then give it back to you with the snap of a finger.
Let's say for the moment that it's true... what purpose does it serve to bring me here?
You said you regretted a great many things from this time in your life. Well, now you have a chance to change some of them.
Change. You mean change the past. Q, even if you have brought me back in time somehow... surely you must realize that any alteration in this timeline could have a profound impact on the future --
Spare me your egotistical musings on your pivotal role in history. Nothing you do here will cause the Federation to collapse or the galaxy to explode. To be blunt... you're not that important.
I won't do it. I won't alter history.

Oh, very well... if you attach so much importance to the continuity of time... I can personally guarantee that nothing you do here will end up hurting anyone, or have an adverse affect on what you know as history. The only thing at stake here is your life and your peace of mind. You have my word.
It's bad form to laugh at one's god. Whether you believe me or not, you're here and you have a second chance... what you do with it is entirely up to you. Do you know where you are?
Starbase Earhart... we came here just after graduation... to wait for our first deep space assignments.

That's right. It's two days before your unfortunate encounter with a Nausicaan sword... you have that long to make whatever changes you wish. If you can avoid getting stabbed through the heart this time -- which I doubt -- I'll take you back to what you think of as the present and you can go on with your life... with a real heart.
So then I won't die?
Of course you'll die. It'll just be at a later time.
What if I don't avoid the fight... what if I don't make any changes?
Then you die on the table and we spend eternity together.
Wonderful.
I'm glad you think so. I am curious about one thing... Johnny, why did that rather attractive woman slap you just now? Something you said?

That woman's name was... Corlina. I was supposed to take her to dinner... on this night... But then she found out that... I'd made a second date with another woman... named Penny. Corlina was... somewhat upset.
I'm impressed. I had no idea you could be such a cad.
Computer, what time is it?
Sixteen eleven hours.
In fact, Penny should be... waiting for me... right now.
You're awfully quiet today. What happened to the dashing young Ensign from last night... the one with the winning smile and the smooth talk about my eyes?
Nothing. I'm just a little more... contemplative.
And what are you contemplating?
Penny, perhaps we could just... talk for a while. I don't know anything about you... where you come from... what your interests are... your last name...
I come from Rigel, my last name is Muroc and I like men in uniform.
I think that's enough talk.
Penny... I don't think it would be fair... to you to pretend that I'm really interested in a... relationship right now...
Who said anything about a relationship?
What's wrong... Don't I look as attractive as I did last night?
What? No, not at all. You're a very... handsome woman.
Handsome... that's something you say to old ladies.
Penny. To me you are definitely not an old lady.
I wasn't after your pity.
Penny for your thoughts?
You never told me you were such a lady's man.
I was a puerile adolescent who let himself be ruled by his hormones instead of his head.
It seems your friends know how to have a good time. Maybe you should go take some lessons.
Hey, you! Get over here with those drinks before I tear your head off!
Excuse me. Are you addressing me... ?
He's winning.
Of course.
I thought you had a date.
She... decided to leave.
You're getting old, Johnny.
Thank you... thank you all...
Very nice... forget about Starfleet and just play Dom-Jot for a living.
This is nothing... it's just a little trigonometry, and some minor wrist action. Barokie -- now there's a game.
Human!
Play Dom-Jot... Human?
I think I could be persuaded to play one more game.
No, don't play him.
Why?
It'll cause trouble.
He's a Nausicaan... they can be very ill-tempered when they lose.
So can I.
Corey, listen to me. This is a bad idea. Don't play him.
What's gotten into you? Let's go.
I see you've found your Nausicaan friend.
You seem un-impaled so far.
Sorry to disappoint you.
Ensign Zweller seems to be doing well.
He's going to lose. The Nausicaan is cheating.
Really? I'm beginning to like these Nausicaans.
If history repeats itself, Corey will figure it out later tonight and then he'll want revenge.
And will you help your best friend avenge this injustice?
I did the first time. I found a way to rig the table so that Corey could win in a rematch.
You? Cheated? Picard, I'm impressed.
It was a foolish mistake. The Nausicaan and his two friends didn't take the loss very well. They were outraged... they wanted a fight... And I gave them one.
A beautiful story... Gets you right here doesn't it?
Dom-Jot! (as if the idea were a joke) Human play Dom-Jot!

I've played a lot of Dom-Jot, in a lot of places, and I've never seen the balls roll that well for anyone. Did you see the way he rolled the terik into straight nines? That's a one in a million shot and he did it twice.
So he was cheating...
It may have simply been extraordinary luck.

I was watching the way he held the cue. Every time he needed to make a tough shot, he held the cue close to his waist. I think he had some kind of magnetic device in his belt. It must've been controlling the balls.
That's terrible.
We have to get even.
What do you have in mind?
We could do the same thing to him that he did to us. Cheat. We'll rig the table so his device will backfire on him.
That won't solve anything.
It'll teach him that he can't go around cheating Starfleet Officers.
What it will do is provoke him. And provoking a Nausicaan is not a good idea.
I can handle him.
What if he's not alone... what if he brings some friends along next time?
Well... then I guess I'll have to depend on my friends to help me out.
Corey... there must be a better way to handle this...
When did you start backing away from a good fight?
We're not cadets anymore... we're officers. We have to start... setting a higher standard for ourselves.
Maybe he's right... maybe this isn't such a good idea.
Look, we've only got one more day before we all have to report to our ships. Let's have one last adventure together... we may not see each other again for a long time.
No. I'm sorry Corey, but I won't do it.
It was a good idea, Corey... but let's just forget about it...
He'll get over it.
I hope so.
What?
Nothing... it's just that usually you'd be the one plotting revenge.
That would be more in character, wouldn't it?
Much. But I always suspected you had a hidden streak of responsibility somewhere.
Maybe I'm just getting... a little older.
Maybe these bars are starting to feel a little heavy, Ensign. Ensign Picard and Ensign Batanides... sounds weird, doesn't it?
It's going to take some getting used to.
It's too bad we can't get used to it together.
The -- the three of us, I mean.
Of course.
Come.
Is there a John-Luck Pickard here?
From one of your conquests, no doubt. I guess some things aren't going to change.
Did I interrupt something sordid I hope?
No, you did not.
Pity. She's quite attractive.
We were friends, nothing more.
Is that another regret I hear?
My, my... we're simply riddled with regrets about our youth, aren't we?
My friendship with Marta is not something I regret.
But you do wish you'd been more than just... friends, don't you? Well... here's your chance to change all that.
What do you want, Q?
I thought you might like to know that Mister Zweller has decided to ignore your advice.
He's in the Bonestell Facility right now... rigging the table to beat the Nausicaan. I guess you weren't that persuasive.
Corey...
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Ow!
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Johnny... don't sneak up on me like that. I thought you were the gambling foreman.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Sorry.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: It's all right. I'm glad you're here. Hand me the magna-spanner.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: I'm not here to help you, I'm here to stop you from making a serious mistake.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: You sound like my mother.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Cheating the Nausicaan could have serious consequences for all of us. It's a risk we can't afford to take.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: You are my mother. Well, Mom... gee, I guess I'll have to go tell the Nausicaans I don't mind if they cheat me --
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: This isn't a joke, Corey.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: It better be.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Now, I'm going to finish my work here. If you want to help me -- fine. If you don't, then I'll see you back at the Starbase.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: I said you're not doing this.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Are you going to hit me, Johnny?
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: No. But I will tell the gambling foreman that someone's been tampering with his Dom-Jot table.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: All right, have it your way... ... Ensign Picard.
scene: 23   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: I just couldn't make him understand.
At least he did finally give it up...
Yes, but... he didn't take it very well.
Oh, you know Corey... he'll forget all about it by tomorrow.
I hope so. We were friends for many years after this. Or at least... I hope we will be.
You keep smiling at me.
I've just never seen you like this before. You're so... serious.
Do I really seem that different?

I don't know... maybe I'm just not used to seeing you in an officer's uniform... (beat, then more thoughtful) No... it's more than that... you do seem different... I mean, I'm not complaining... I think it suits you.
Really?
Yes. I think it's very... ... attractive.
Johnny... have you ever thought about us... getting together?
Actually... I have. For a long time.
Why didn't you ever say so?
I... don't know. At the moment... I can't imagine why I didn't...
Well... you've said it now.
Good morning, darling.
A little jumpy this morning, are we? Feeling guilty perhaps?
I don't have anything to feel guilty about, Q.
No? "We were friends, Q. Nothing more."
You're the one who gave me the opportunity to change things...
So what happens next?
I don't know. But I do know that things will be different.
I'm sure.
Morning.
Johnny.
What's wrong?
Well... this is the morning after, huh?
I suppose so.
I... don't quite know where to begin...
Marta... I don't regret what happened last night... and I hope you don't, either.
I don't know... we've been friends for a long time... and now...
I hope last night has only brought us closer.
Do you remember the first day we reported to the Academy?
Very well.

They marched us into Scobee Hall in our stiff new uniforms... and then Admiral Silona gave us the old welcome aboard speech. He said, I want you all to look to the left of you and then look to the right of you...
... One of you isn't going to make it through the next four years.

I remember thinking... that's me. I'm not going to make it. Then I looked to my right... and there you were with this cocky look on your face... and you said, "we'll see about that." From that moment, I knew I wanted you as a friend.
And now... I'm afraid we've ruined that friendship.
Perhaps we should just... pretend that this never happened and try to...

I wish I could. It would make it easier to say good-bye tomorrow. We're all supposed to get together later... the last big night on the town before we ship out... now I'm not sure it's such a good idea...
I don't want you to do anything that'll be uncomfortable...
I'll be there. We planned this... I don't want to disappoint Corey.

Let's see... in the past twenty-four hours, you've managed to get slapped by one woman, have a drink thrown in your face by another, and alienate your two best friends. I'd say you're doing quite nicely so far.
Just one more thing to do... avoid getting stabbed through the heart tonight.
I think you'll like serving aboard the Ajax... I understand Captain Narth is an excellent officer.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: So I hear.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Well... here's to the class of 'twenty-seven.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Play Dom-Jot, Human? Give you a better chance. Give you a bigger stick maybe.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: I don't think we're interested.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: They are Undari. Cowards.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: What did you say?
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Coward. Like all Starfleet. You talk and you talk... but you have no guramba.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Why don't we find out --
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Don't be a fool. There are plenty of other people to play Dom-Jot. Go on about your business.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Maybe I play with you... give you a good time.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Orcho lok resnik Starfleet...
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: You've done enough.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Corey, I'm sorry. He was drawing a weapon...
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: I don't know who you are anymore... but you're not my friend.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Good-bye, Johnny.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Congratulations, Mon Capitain. You did it.
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Can I help you?
scene: 28   INT. BONESTELL FACILITY - GAMBLING CENTER - NIGHT

quote: Can I help you, Mister Picard?
Worf...
This is not for me. You should take it to Commander La Forge in Engineering.
What's happened... ?
Is something wrong?
I'm not sure... Mister Worf, what's my rank and position?
You are a Lieutenant junior grade... the assistant astrophysics officer.
Are you feeling all right?
Who's the Captain of this ship?
Captain Thomas Halloway. Perhaps I should escort you to Sickbay.
No. I think I can find my way. Thank you, Commander.
Beverly, something's happened to me. I'm not sure --
Vhat seems to be de trouble, Lieutenant Picard?
Q, what have you done?
I've done exactly what I promised, Jean-Luc. I've returned you to the present.
This is not the present I remember. You said nothing would change.

And nothing has changed... except for you. But then, that's what you wanted, wasn't it? To change the man you were in your youth? Well, you did it -- and this is the man you are today. You should be happy... you have a real heart beating in your chest and you get to live out the rest of your life in safety... running tests... making analyses... and carrying reports to your superiors.
... so tell Duffy that we'll need to adjust the main deflector later this afternoon. Oh, and have him look into that inducer problem.
Hi, Jean-Luc. What's new in astrophysics? Do you need something?
I have the... spectral analysis for you.
Thanks. Lynch, try shunting the power through the lateral conduit.
So where's the problem... ?
What's going on?
Oh, something's causing a power spike in the starboard warp coil. If I don't track it down soon, the Captain's going to have my head on a platter.
Have you tried flushing the transfer conduits with trioxina?
No.
The conduits sometimes get blocked by neutrino emissions when the plasma --
Hey... I know you're trying to make full Lieutenant this year... but I think we can handle this from here.
Am I interrupting?
Not at all. Have a seat.
I wonder if I could talk with you for a moment... about my future on the Enterprise.
Of course, Lieutenant. Jean-Luc, isn't it?
Maybe I should go.
No, please Counselor... I would very much like to hear your thoughts...
First of all... I'd like you to be straightforward with me. How do you evaluate me as an officer?
Your performance reports have always been good. You're thorough... dedicated...
Reliable, steady... (beat, then, unable to come up with anything else) ...punctual.
I see. What would you say if I told you I thought I was capable of being more than that...
Maybe we should discuss this at your next evaluation...
I'd very much appreciate it if we could discuss it now.
I would like to try... to move beyond astrophysics... into engineering or security perhaps. Something which might even lead to a command.
Frankly, Lieutenant... I don't think that's realistic...
Why?
I really don't think this is the place to be discussing --
Please. This is important to me. I know I can do more.
Hasn't this been the problem all along? Throughout your career... you've had lofty goals... but you've never been willing to do what's necessary to attain them.
Would that be your evaluation as well, Commander?

I'd have to agree with the Counselor. You talk about wanting more... but when it comes to doing something about it, you hang back. If you want to get ahead, you have to take chances... stand out from the crowd... get noticed.
I see.
(trying to salve the wound) We don't want to lose you... you're a good officer.
Just not -- one who stands out.
Look... why don't I talk to Commander La Forge... maybe there's something in Engineering.
But... command?
Well... we'll see.
Senior officers please report to the Captain's Ready Room.
Acknowledged.
I think we should talk about this later.
All right, Q. Enough of this. You've made your point.
La Forge to Lieutenant Picard. I'm still waiting for your final sensor usage log.
I'm on my way, sir.
Main Engineering.
Are you having a good laugh now, Q? Does it amuse you to think of me living out the rest of my life as a dreary man in a tedious job?
I gave you something most mortals never experience... a second chance at life. And now all you can do is complain?
I can't live out my days as that person. That man is bereft of passion and imagination. That's not who I am.
Au contraire. He's the person you wanted to be... one who was less arrogant, and undisciplined as a youth. One who was less like me.
The Jean-Luc Picard you wanted to be, the one who did not fight the Nausicaan, had quite a different career from the one you remember.

That Picard never had a brush with death... never came face to face with his own mortality... never realized how fragile life is... how important each moment can be... so his life never came into focus. He drifted through much of his career, with no plan or agenda... going from one assignment to the next, never seizing the opportunities that presented themselves... He didn't lead the Away Team on Milika Three to save that ambassador... he didn't take charge of the Stargazer's Bridge when its Captain was killed... and no one ever offered him a command. He learned to play it safe. And he never, ever got noticed by anyone.
You're right. You gave me the chance to change and I took that opportunity. But I freely admit now that it was a mistake.
Are you asking me for something, Jean-Luc?
Yes. Give me a chance to put things back to the way they were before.
Before, you died in Sickbay. Is that what you want?
I would rather die as the man I was... than live the life I just saw.
Please.
Coward. Like all Starfleet. You talk and you talk... but you have no guramba.
What did you say?
I said you are a coward.
That's what I thought you said.
His vital signs are stabilizing... Captain... ? Jean-Luc... ?
You've been injured... but I think it's going to be all right.
... I still don't know what to make of it all. Was it a dream? Or one of Q's elaborate tricks?
A lot of people who've been near death have talked about strange experiences... but they're not usually so detailed.
Part of me cannot accept the idea that Q would have given me a second chance... that he would demonstrate that much... compassion. But if it was Q... I owe him a debt of gratitude.
In what sense? It sounds like he put you through hell.

There were many things in my youth that I'm not proud of... they were loose threads... untidy parts of myself that I wanted to remove. But when I pulled on one of those threads... I unravelled the tapestry of my life.
I was just trying to imagine you as a hell-bent-for-leather young officer insulting a Nausicaan twice your size. I wish I'd gotten a chance to meet that Jean-Luc Picard.
Well, to tell the truth... that wasn't the first time I'd had a run-in with a couple of surly Nausicaans...
Really?
Oh, yes... During my sophomore year I was assigned to do some training on Morikin Seven. Well, there was a Nausicaan outpost on one of the outlying asteroids...
Geordi... Have you found it yet?
Not yet...
Starting to get fumes... Ammonia, fluorine, potassium cyanide...
I can feel the heat from here.
There it is!
How far?
About ten meters. Along the ODN line. It's hot -- over two thousand degrees. I'm going in.
Geordi, wait.
We're okay... I've activated the emergency supression system.
It's under control.
All his vital functions are completely normal.
The interface unit is operating within expected parameters.
Why did he start coughing when he went through the gasses?
Psychosomatic response.
I feel like I'm actually here... I mean there -- in the Jefferies tube. I saw the smoke and I couldn't help coughing.
No one else has reported so complete a sensory experience.
The interface is perfect for Geordi because his VISOR inputs allow the probe to transmit information directly into his cerebral cortex.
It looks like this is going to work. Let's get the probe out of the Jefferies tube and into the launch bay before we reach Marijne Seven.
Will do...
Something's wrong. I'm having trouble controlling my left leg.
What is it?
The probe is designed to respond to the movements Geordi intends to make -- when his brain sends a message to move his leg, the interface moves the probe instead.
Apparently the gain on the tactile sensors is too low; I will increase the input.
There it goes.
I'm on my way down.
Why the body-suit?
It provides tactile sensations so that Geordi will feel as if he is in the same environment as the probe.
What's wrong?
Nothing...
I just saw my reflection in a panel. I forgot what a handsome guy I am.

Captain's Log, Stardate 47215.5. We are responding to a distress call from the science vessel Raman, which is apparently trapped inside the turbulent atmosphere of an unusual gas giant planet. We will use an experimental interface probe in our attempt to rescue it.
I have reviewed the vessel's mission plans. The Raman was to descend to the lower atmosphere, eleven thousand kilometers below its current position...
The crew was to sample the atmosphere at that level, and then return to a safer orbit.
Something must have happened down there. Maybe the shields failed, or they had an inversion reaction in the nacelles.
Any life signs?
Our bio-sensors are useless -- there's too much interference in the atmosphere.
The crew might still be alive. But we'll never be able to tell from up here.
Will the probe be able to transmit through the interference?
The probe sends information via a focused particle beam that should be able to cut through the interference.
But we may have to operate the interface at near tolerance levels.
Will your nervous system be able to handle that much sensory input?
We've tested the interface at up to seventy percent of tolerance.
There shouldn't be a problem going higher -- the safety override will kick in at ninety-eight percent tolerance and disengage the interface.
Captain, I am receiving a transmission from Starfleet Command -- Admiral Holt.
In my Ready Room.
The seven people on that ship are our first priority. Is the probe ready for launch?
Yes, Sir.
Send it directly to the aft section of the Raman, through the secondary air lock. That'll put it one bulkhead away from the Bridge.
I'll interface with the probe as soon as it's in place and take it in the rest of the way.
Make it so.
Onscreen.
Hello, Marcus.
Jean-Luc.
How's life on DS-Three?
We're hosting this year's palio. The Ferengi have already been accused of trying to bribe the Breen pilot into throwing the race...
Nothing unusual about that.
Nothing at all...

I wish I could say I was just calling to catch up on things. Nine days ago, the Hera left here on a routine courier mission. We were in contact with them for five of those days. Then the ship disappeared without a trace.
The Hera?
I'm afraid so.

The Excelsior and the Noble have spent the last seventy-two hours retracing its course. Nothing. I'm going to keep them at it for seventy-two more. But to be honest, I don't think another week would make any difference.
I'll tell Commander La Forge...
Mister Data, I need a word with Commander La Forge.
Yes, Sir. I will be on the Bridge.
I've just spoken to Starfleet. The Hera is missing.
Missing... ?
What about my mother... ?
Captain La Forge has disappeared along with the rest of her crew...
-- I saw your father last week and your sister about ten days before that. I decided I missed my favorite son...
Your only son, Mom...

You're going to have to see the Hera again. We've got a lot of new faces on board. Including a chief engineer who juices up the nacelles every chance she gets. I think she's the best technician in the fleet. Okay, second best.
Come in...
I didn't mean to interrupt.
Don't worry about it.
Maybe you should meet her. We're going to be in the same sector next week. Take a shuttle over and I'll introduce you.
Mom's always trying to find me a wife.
But if you're too busy, I'll see you at your father's birthday party. Remember, if you talk to him -- it's a surprise.
This came in about three weeks ago. I never got back to her...
Geordi, the probe has entered the planet's atmosphere. I'm ready to move it inside the ship. If you want to take a couple of days off, I'll run the interface.
The interface is calibrated specifically for my VISOR inputs. You'd need at least ten hours to convert it. Those crewmen down there can't wait...
The interface doesn't have to be fully compatible. I could use it right now. I wouldn't have the control you'd have, but it would still work.
Forget it. I'm the best one for the job, and there's no reason not to go ahead as planned.
The Hera is reason enough.
The Hera is missing. That's all. Until I hear something more, my mother might just as well have taken the crew on an unscheduled holiday.
Let's go.
Sir, the probe is through the airlock and in position aboard the Raman.
Picard to Commander Data. Report.
We are ready to bring the interface on line.
Proceed.
Activating the remote sensors...
Initiating interface... now.
Vital signs normal... How do you feel, Geordi?
Fine...
Do you have visual contact?
Not yet...
Increase the input signal, Data. I'm not seeing anything...
scene: 20   INT. SCIENCE SHIP CORRIDOR - GEORDI'S POV (OPTICAL)

quote: Acknowledged.
scene: 20   INT. SCIENCE SHIP CORRIDOR - GEORDI'S POV (OPTICAL)

quote: I can see. But no colors.
Increasing signal strength of seventy-five percent of tolerance.
That's better.
scene: 22   INT. SCIENCE SHIP CORRIDOR - GEORDI'S POV (OPTICAL)

quote: Your pulse has gone up...
scene: 22   INT. SCIENCE SHIP CORRIDOR - GEORDI'S POV (OPTICAL)

quote: It might take your nervous system a little while to get used to this input level.
I'm excited, that's all. This is like being on a roller coaster.
Or a first date... Everything's okay.
I'll be the judge of that, Geordi. If your heart rate goes too high, we'll disconnect you.
Understood. But don't pull the plug yet...
It's a mess in here. There must be a hull breach somewhere. I'm picking up atmospheric gasses inside the corridor -- methane and ammonia primarily.
I'm heading toward the Bridge.
It's getting worse the closer I get. The break in the hull might be on the Bridge itself.
I found somebody!
What is your position?
About twelve meters up the main corridor! A section of the bulkhead collapsed on top of him.
I can't move it. I need more power to the tractor beams.
Go to eighty percent of tolerance -- no higher.
He looks pretty bad.
He's dead.
Data, the door halfway down the left corridor... what's it lead to?
A magnetic storage bay.
If there was a breach on the Bridge, that would be the safest place to go.
Data, I need a phaser burst. Wide focus, level four intensity.
I've found them!
They're dead... all of them.
There's a fire in here...
Data! Disconnect him!
What happened?
I don't know... My hands...
They're burned...
How did this happen?
There was some kind of energy discharge in the interface suit.
Shouldn't the safety over-rides have prevented that?
Yes... but I have a theory why they didn't.
The tolerance levels on the interface were set extremely high. I think Geordi's neural response to the input was so strong that it created a feedback loop.
The sensors that were transmitting the sensation of heat to my hands must've overloaded.
I know it seems hard to believe, but the probe was sending huge amounts of sensory data directly into Geordi's brain. The tolerance levels on the interface were set extremely high.
The Raman's crew is dead. I'd like to retrieve their vessel, but not if it means risking Geordi's safety.
If we turn down the sensory input from the probe, I should be fine.
Seven people lost their lives down there... we should at least retrieve the data they were collecting. Otherwise their deaths won't have any meaning.
Doctor?
If we operate the interface at lower input levels, I'd say the risk is acceptable.
Alright. Picard to Riker.
Riker, here.
The Raman's crew is dead. I'd like to retrieve their vessel, but not if it means risking Geordi's safety.
If we turn down the sensory input from the probe, I should be fine.
Seven people lost their lives down there... we should at least retrieve the data they were collecting.
Doctor?
If we operate the interface at lower input levels, I'd say the risk is acceptable.
Alright. Picard to Riker.
Riker, here.
I've decided to proceed with the probe.
We'll have to take it into the Raman's auxiliary control room -- the Bridge is too badly damaged.
How long before you can get it into position?
A few hours -- we're going to have to cut through a bulkhead.
Acknowledged.
Looks like you'll have some time to recuperate.
There's something I need to do anyway.
How are you, Dad?
As well as expected, given the circumstances. Are you okay?
Yeah...

I talked to your sister this morning. She said she'd get in touch with you in a few days. Right now she's pretty upset. The service for the Hera will probably be on Vulcan -- most of the crew was from there. But your sister and I want to have a private ceremony --
-- Dad. Don't you think everybody's jumping the gun here?
Last I heard, two starships were still out there looking. They've found no debris, no residual warp distortion --
-- And no ship.
Not yet. That doesn't mean they won't.
Starfleet is considering the Hera lost. The search isn't much more than a formality at this point. Geordi, your mother's gone...
You can think that if you want. But until I see some hard evidence, I'm not going to give up hope.
All right, Geordi. Call me if you need anything...
Come in.
Hey, Data. Still working?
No. I have completed the adjustments on the interface. I am now waiting for Commander Riker to finish moving the probe.
Do you wish to be comforted?
No... I was just passing by. Wondered what you were up to.
I am using the time to catch up on my study of poetry.
Data, there's nothing on the screen.
That is not entirely correct. While it is true the display is currently blank, this emptiness has a poetic meaning. So it cannot be considered "nothing" as such.
Says who?

The ancient Doosodarians. Much of their poetry contained such "lacunae" or empty spaces. Often these pauses measured several days in length, during which poet and audience were encouraged to fully acknowledge the emptiness of the experience.
I remember some lectures at Starfleet academy that seemed like that.
Are you certain you do not wish to talk about your mother?
Why do you ask that?

You are no doubt feeling emotional distress as a result of her disappearance. Though you claimed to be "just passing by," that is most likely an excuse to start a conversation about this uncomfortable subject. Am I correct?
Well, no. Sometimes "just passing by" means "just passing by."
Then I apologize for my premature assumption.
This particular poem has a lacuna of forty-seven minutes. You may experience the emptiness with me if you wish.
Thanks...
Data, maybe you gave up too fast.
I do not understand.
When I said "just passing by" means "just passing by" -- I didn't really mean it.
My initial assumption was correct. You do wish to speak of your mother.
Am I crazy to think she's still alive?
Your sanity is not in question. However, your evaluation of the available information is... biased.
She's the captain of a starship! She's gotten herself into and out of impossible situations before. Why should this be any different?
Disappearances fitting the profile of the Hera have rarely ended with the safe recovery of ship and crew.
That makes me feel better.
I'm sorry, Data. I didn't mean to snap at you.
I am not offended. You are upset and your reactions are not surprising.
I guess I am a little... on edge.
It's just that... If she really is dead... I don't know what I'm going to do...
We're receiving the probe's telemetry.
The input levels are currently at fifty-three percent of tolerance.
That's too low, Data. I won't be able to do anything down there.
I want to start with as wide a margin of safety as possible. We can adjust upward as needed. Ready?
Go ahead.
Initiating interface...
I can't see anything.
I am increasing input now...
That's better... but I need more...
Is this level sufficient?
Geordi?
Geordi, can you hear me?
Mom...
Mom, is it you?
Is it you... ?
I forgot! All you're seeing is a probe. Yes, it's me. I'm on the Enterprise. I'm interfaced with this probe.
Geordi. Who are you talking to? What are you seeing?
But is it really you?
Yes, Geordi. It's me.
How can it be... ? How is it possible --
There's no time to explain. We have to go down...
Down where?
The surface.
Geordi. Report.
Hang on, Doctor...
Why? Why do we have to go to the surface?
We're dying.
"We?" Your ship? The Hera is down there?
Geordi, we're disconnecting you right now...
No. Wait...
We need your help. I need your help... Geordi...
The cut-off has been automatically activated.
He's in neural shock --
The sensory overload didn't cause any permanent damage -- but I wouldn't want to expose his nervous system to that much stimulus again.
Is there any indication of what caused the hallucination?
His brain functions are normal --
I told you, I wasn't hallucinating.
Geordi, I have analyzed the probe's sensor logs -- there are no readings that would indicate the presence of a living human on board the Raman.
She wasn't actually there. Her ship is on the surface.
Then you believe you saw some kind of... transmission?
Somehow she managed to contact me.
We have no indication of a transmission of any kind.
Maybe I'm the only one who could detect it -- because I was interfaced with the probe.
The probe does allow Geordi to sense quantum fluctuations, subspace anomalies, and other phenomena not perceptible to other kinds of sensors.
Granted. But why would he perceive his mother visually, as if she were standing in the room?

I'm not sure... I do know that our brains aren't designed to process the kind of sensory information Geordi was getting. When the brain receives something it can't understand, it interprets the input as best it can -- sometimes as a sound or smell, sometimes visually.
You see?
Geordi, that doesn't mean you're mother was really communicating with you. I'm just trying to explain why you might've thought she was.
I'm telling you, my mother's ship is trapped down there -- they need our help.
The Hera's last reported location was over three hundred light years away. How could it have ended up here?
If the Hera is on the surface, its hull could not possibly withstand the pressure of the atmosphere.
Just let me go back so we can be sure.
I don't recommend he use the interface again -- the sensory overload nearly killed him.
I'll be all right.
I'm sorry, Geordi. But I won't risk your life.
Mister Data, find another way to salvage the Raman. I want to hear an alternate plan in two hours.
Yes, Captain.
In the meantime, I'd like you to talk with Counselor Troi. She's expecting you.
Aye, Sir...
What's your mother like, Geordi?
Counselor, if you think I'm going to start talking about my childhood, you're way off.
That's not what I asked.

No, I guess not. She was -- She is... brilliant, funny... really perceptive. She knows people. Knows what they're all about even before they open their mouths. She's always been like that. A good judge of character.
When did you see her last?
Seven months ago, when she first took command of the Hera. I went to a party she had for her crew...

The Enterprise and the Hera were in the same sector three weeks ago. She wanted to see me. We were both pretty busy though... I guess I could have made the time. But I didn't think... I mean I just didn't think...
You didn't think it would be your last chance to see her...
You don't know that! None of us does!
I'm going to suggest something. Call it a theory. Alright?
Alright...

You're very worried about the disappearance of your mother... and guilty over not seeing her when you had the chance. So you're unwilling even to consider that she might be dead. This need to believe she's alive is so strong, it manifested itself as a physical image.
But she told me she's trapped on the planet! She's in danger! If this was some kind of wish fulfillment, don't you think I'd fantasize her being safe and sound?
No. Because that would end the fantasy -- you'd know it wasn't true. The more involved and complicated and unending your story is, the longer you can believe your mother is still alive.
That's your theory, Counselor. I've got a different one.
I have been exploring the possibility of using a tractor beam to pull the Raman from the atmosphere. However, there is so much interference that it prevents a positive lock.
If we could set up some sort of relay system...
That is my conclusion as well, Commander. Two shuttlecraft, staggered between the Enterprise and the Raman, with their shields adjusted to refocus the tractor beam.
Can we get those shuttles close enough without putting them in danger? Mister La Forge.
I suppose so. Yes. As long as you keep them above the troposphere, they'll be alright.
In that case --
What about the Hera?
We'll be leaving my mother and her crew stranded on the planet. We have to save them.
Commander --
-- I've been thinking about this...
A few weeks ago I got a message from my mother. She said she had a new chief engineer who was always experimenting with the warp drive.
Well, I've seen the Hera -- it uses trionic initiators in the warp coil. They have a history of strange side effects -- especially if you start playing around with them.
There have been reports of warp bubbles and other subspace deformations.
So what if that's what happened? Not a warp bubble, but a subspace funnel.
Connecting two points through subspace.
The Hera could have accidentally created a distortion that emptied out right here, on Marijne Seven.
Why here?
The Hera passed near this planet just ten days ago. There's a lot of subspace distortion in the atmosphere -- the ship might've picked up some residual traces that directed the funnel back here.
And the Hera is still in one piece, down on the surface?
Maybe it's surrounded by some kind of subspace field that's keeping it together. But who knows for how long?
Do you have any evidence to support this... hypothesis?
I did get some strange subspace readings when I was interfaced with the probe.
Geordi, that could be anything.
I talked to her. She asked me to take the Raman closer to the planet.
Is any of this possible?
Yes.
There.
However, I believe it is... unlikely.
How unlikely?
Nearly impossible, Sir.
Proceed with the shuttle plan.
Captain --
-- Mister La Forge. Stay here for a moment.
Geordi, I'm not unsympathetic about what you're going through. But I want you to consider my position as well.
Yes, Sir.
Your mother's disappearance... It's... a tragic thing... But I can't risk your safety on the basis of a dubious hypothesis.
If there's even one chance in a million I'm right and she's alive...
I'm sorry, Geordi. I've made my decision.
I understand, Sir.
I suspected you would decide to operate the interface alone.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: You did?
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I am familiar enough with your behavior patterns to predict certain... decisions.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I guess you know me pretty well...
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: You are disobeying the Captain.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I can't just sit back and do nothing when my mother might be down on that planet.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I can not allow you to endanger your well being.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: If we leave here without knowing for sure...
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I'll have to live with it for the rest of my life... wondering... if I left her to die... I couldn't take that, Data... I couldn't...
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: That's why I have to do this.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I could have you confined to quarters for the duration of the mission.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: If you want to do that to me, Data, then go ahead. Because nothing less is going to stop me from trying to save my mother.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: What are you doing?
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I will monitor the interface and attempt to keep you safe.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I can not have you confined to quarters for something you have not yet done.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: Data, we could both end up in a lot of trouble for this.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: There is a high degree of probability that you are right.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: Thanks, Data.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: However, I have a request.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: What's that?
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I would ask you to consider the possibility that what you see is not real.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I will. I promise.
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: I am establishing the interface...
scene: 48   INT. LAB - ON THE INTERFACE CONSOLE

quote: Mom... ?
Hello, Geordi...
How did you get here?
I'm not really with you, Geordi. I'm on my ship, on the surface. We were pulled into a warp funnel.
That's just what I thought!
How are we communicating?
We found a way to send a subspace signal that could cut through the atmospheric interference.
Geordi, are you seeing the image of your mother... ?
Yes, and she just confirmed everything I've been saying.
I am reading some unusual subspace energy in your vicinity -- similar to what the probe sensors recorded the first time you encountered your mother.
That's how she's communicating with me. It's the only kind of signal they could send that would get through the interference.
We need your help.
I've been thinking about this -- I'm going to take the Raman into a low stationary orbit and initiate an inverse warp cascade.
Why?
The subspace distortion from the cascade should reverse the warp funnel -- your ship will end up right where it started.
Geordi, the atmosphere becomes increasingly turbulent the farther down you go -- you may not be able to bring the Raman close enough to the Hera before being destroyed.
I have to try, Data.
We're running out of time.
Shields back on line... we're starting our descent...
Thank god...
Thank... god...
That you're alive -- that I was right about all this. I can't wait to call Dad. He and Ariana had given up...
We're going home...
Eventually, yeah.
Data -- everything's fading in and out.
I'm losing the interface.
The probe is descending out of range.
You're going to have to turn up the input gain to maintain my connection.
It is already at seventy-five percent of tolerance.
You can take it all the way up to a hundred if you increase it slowly enough -- give my nervous system time to adapt.
That is theoretically true. But even at this input level you have already experienced dangerous neural feedback.
Data, there are over three hundred people on board the Hera. We're the only chance they've got.
I will increase the gain incrementally as you descend.
It's working.
When we are ready to disconnect the interface, we must allow sufficient time to lower the input levels -- otherwise your nervous system would go into shock from the sudden drop in input.
Once I initiate the warp cascade we can start dropping the gain.
We'll be in sensor range of your ship within a few minutes.
I'm sorry I didn't get over to see you a few weeks ago.
You were... too busy with work.
I'm sorry; it won't happen again.
Captain, the Raman is descending toward the planet.
Geordi...
Geordi, we are now at ninety percent of tolerance.
My calculations show that you will reach one hundred percent of tolerance before you are in range of the Hera.
Then we're going to have to go beyond tolerance.
That is not advisable. You must cease your descent.
Geordi, don't stop... please.
Data, I'm taking this ship down. If you don't boost the gain past tolerance levels, I'll lose the interface when we go out of range and my nervous system will go into shock.
You are putting me in a very difficult position. Please cease your descent.
I won't do it... so you'd better increase the tolerance...
Disengaging safety systems... going to full tolerance levels... now.
Thanks, Data.
We're getting close...
Thank god...
La Forge.
Yes, Captain?
Stop your descent and prepare to disengage the interface.
I'm sorry, sir. But I can't do that.
Damn it, Geordi -- you're going to kill yourself...
If I come back now, my mother and her entire crew will die. (reads monitor; to Silva) I'm scanning for your ship... I'm not getting anything.
We're still too far away...
Not really. I should be picking something up by now.
I'm not finding anything... No warp funnel... No ship... There's nothing there.
His neural synapses are overloading. He can't survive this...
Geordi -- what's happening to you?
Geordi!
Reverse tractors -- Reverse --
Reversing tractor beams...
What are you?
You are killing us... We must go down.
Geordi... Report.
You're trapped... ?
Is there any way we can disconnect him?
If we cut him off abruptly, he'll go into neural shock.
How can we lower the input gradually and still get him out before it's too late?
Perhaps we can deceive his neural receptors.
Deceive them?
By feeding them the sensory information recorded from his earlier experiences with the probe.
We could disconnect the interface and still maintain the input levels.
We could then lower them in a controlled manner.
Like a decompression tank. Let's try it.
Captain. I have to take the ship into the lower atmosphere...
Explain.

As I understand it... when the Raman got close to the planet, they accidentally picked up some lifeforms that live in the lower atmosphere. Subspace beings of some kind -- intelligent. When the ship went back into a higher orbit, the beings were trapped.
How do you know all this?
One of them is able to communicate with me. It must have read my thoughts through the probe interface and took the form of my Mother -- to try to talk me into taking the ship closer to the surface.
Were these beings responsible for the death of the Raman's crew?

Yes, but I don't think it was on purpose. They probably tried to communicate with them the same way they're communicating with me -- by directly accessing their thoughts. That must've been fatal to the crew... I guess the interface protected me.
I have to take them back -- they can't survive so far up in the atmosphere.
I'll turn the ship around and come back as soon as we're --
La Forge! What happened?
The atmosphere is getting more turbulent. It's overloading the systems.
I'm having trouble keeping the shields up.
Geordi...
We're safe now...
Good bye...
I'm losing power...
Total shield failure in eight seconds...
Are you ready to switch inputs?
Almost.
Shields are failing...
Switching inputs!
Is it working?
His vital signs are stabilizing. He's going to make it.
Captain's Log, supplemental. We have succeeded in disengaging Mister La Forge from the interface and are en route to Starbase four-nine-five.
You disobeyed my direct order, and you put yourself in grave danger. I'm not happy.
It's my fault, sir. Data was just --
I'll deal with Data at another time. Meanwhile, I'll have to write this incident into your permanent record.
Yes, sir.
Geordi...
I'm very sorry you didn't find your mother.
Thank you, sir. When I was down there... it was so real. It's funny, but in a way... I feel like I got a chance to say goodbye...
You're trapped?
Caught on the ship...
You killed the Raman's crew?
What do you want?
You really did it this time, Wil. It's not just a scrape... it's a deep cut.
I can heal it... but it would serve you right if I didn't.
You can't keep playing Parises Squares like you're twenty-one years old. One of these days you're going to fall and break your neck... and I won't be able to heal that so easily.
Actually... I wasn't playing Parises Squares...
Mmm... Worf's calisthenic program again...
No...
Oh? What were you doing?
I was trying to feed Spot.
Data's cat?
I told Data I'd feed it while he was away...
All I remember is setting down the food... and then a hissing ball of fur came out of nowhere. I hate cats.
You've just got to know how to handle them.
Maybe you'd like to feed Spot.
I'd be happy to...
Commander Riker to the Bridge.
On my way.
Oh, and Doctor...
You're going to need this.
Report.
We are picking up a distress call on the long range sensors. It is Romulan, sir.
Romulan?
They claim they have suffered a complete engine failure. Their power levels are dropping... and their life support is failing. It could be a trick.
How long until our rendezvous with Captain Picard?
Approximately thirteen hours.
Set course for the Romulan ship, Mister Worf. Raise our shields, and go to Red Alert. I want to be ready for anything.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46944.2. Commander Data, Mister La Forge, Counselor Troi and I are en route to the Enterprise, after attending a three day conference on the psychological effects of long-term deep space assignments.
Computer -- activate automatic helm control.
Helm control activated.
So just as I'm leaving the reception, a Ktarian walks up to me and says...
"So Diane... I understand you're an empath. I'm a very... sensitive man myself. I'm doing a thesis on interspecies mating rituals. Would you care to join me in some empirical research?"
Don't tell me -- Doctor Mizan.
That's right.
He's notorious. But he really is an expert on interspecies mating practices.
Did you help him with his research, Counselor?
Absolutely not.
But I thought that topic interested you.
Yes... but...
I'll explain it to you later, Data.
What did you think of the rest of the conference?

To be honest... I was bored. I spent most of my time in Doctor Wagner's phylobiology seminar. I thought the idea of a seminar was that we would all participate... bring different points of views to the discussion...
He gathered two hundred scientists from all over the Federation... and all he did was put us to sleep.
I have a memory record of the entire lecture, Counselor. I can repeat the portions you missed, if you --
No thank you, Data.

It wasn't any better at the physiognomy workshop. Doctor Vassbinder gave an hour long dissertation on the ionization effect of warp nacelles -- before he realized the topic was supposed to be psychology.
Why didn't somebody tell him?
There was never an opportunity -- never a pause. He just kept talking... like he was speaking in one incredibly long, run-on sentence. It was almost... hypnotic.
Well, I had a good time. The warp energy symposium was fascinating. I actually got the chance to touch a plasma field.
Really. What was it like?
Incredible. I could feel the plasma crawling up my arm. It was warm... and it gave off a tingling sensation that --
Captain? Data... ?
-- went all the way down my chest. It was kind of like taking a bath in pure energy.
It was not painful?
Not at all. In fact...
Is there something wrong, Counselor?
I'm... not sure...
Our bio-scans check out. There are no physiological anomalies. If something did happen, it didn't leave any biological traces.
How long did it appear to you that we were... frozen?
I don't know... four, maybe five seconds. You just... stopped... and then started again... I can't explain it...
My memory record does not indicate a pause or disruption during that period of time.
My internal chronometer and the ship's computer are perfectly synchronized. There does not appear to be a temporal discrepancy.
Data -- let's run a ship-wide diagnostic. Maybe there's something we missed...
Let's go through it again. You were sitting there... and we were sitting here... Describe the exact moment when things appeared to freeze.
Geordi was talking about what it felt like to touch the plasma field... You were lifting the cup, about to take a drink...
Did you sense anything from us during that time? Any unusual emotions?
No... not a thing. I was empathically aware of you, right up to the moment you froze, but then it all stopped...
The past few days have been exhausting. Maybe it was my imagination... There were moments in that lecture hall when I thought time was standing still, too...
There is another possibility, Counselor. Perhaps this was nothing more than a simple --
Are you alright?
What happened?
You have been motionless for three minutes, eleven seconds.
Motionless... ?
It appears to be the same effect you described to us. Can you remember anything?
No... one second I was sitting here talking with you... the next, you were all standing around me.
Wait a second... this is weird...
What is it?

I had the tricorder run a comparison between the bio-scan I took of you earlier... and the one I took just now... In the time between the two scans, you should have aged twenty-three minutes. But according to your cellular decay levels... you've only aged twenty minutes.
What could account for the discrepancy?
I don't know, sir. It's as if for three minutes, time stopped for Counselor Troi.
Mister Data -- contact the Enterprise. Tell Commander Riker to get to the rendezvous point as soon as possible. Have him begin scanning the region for temporal anomalies.
Aye sir.
I'll take a look at the sensor logs... see if I can find anything.
Captain.
The Enterprise is not responding to our hails.
Are we within sensor range yet?
No sir.
Increase speed to the rendezvous coordinates.
Aye sir.
We have an engine failure warning in the --
Report!
The starboard nacelle just cut out!
Attitude control has been restored.
Full stop. What happened?
The starboard antimatter pod is completely drained. The fuel reserves are empty.
Is there a containment leak?
No sir. The containment field is intact... all engine systems are operational... The fuel is just gone.
Geordi -- I believe I have an explanation. According to the plasma conversion sensor, the starboard engine has been in continuous operation for over forty-seven days.
Forty-seven days? Let's take a look at that sensor -- it must be malfunctioning.
I'll check the fuel consumption logs...
What happened?
My hand...
The cells in your hand are metabolizing at an incredible rate... almost fifty times normal...
The pain is going away...
Your metabolism is stabilizing...
It happened when I reached for the bowl of fruit.

Captain. I am detecting a temporal disturbance which intersects the table. It would appear that within this disturbance, time is moving at a highly accelerated rate -- approximately fifty times faster than normal.
The disturbance is roughly spherical in shape. It extends outward through the hull, approximately seventeen meters beyond the ship.
That would cover the starboard nacelle. No wonder it used up all its fuel.
Check the hull integrity.
It does not appear to be affected.
See if you can move us away from the disturbance, Mister La Forge.
Aye sir.
Lateral thrusters on-line... Data, plot a course away from the disturbance. Make sure it doesn't come in contact with our other engine.
Course plotted. Adjust pitch to twenty-seven point three degrees. Set heading one-eight-zero mark zero.
Got it. Reversing at fifteen meters per second...
We are clearing the phenomenon...
All stop.
What's the matter?
There is another temporal disturbance directly behind us.
Captain, you'd better take a look at this...
The sensors are picking up temporal disturbances throughout the region. Different configurations... different sizes... they're everywhere.
Within each disturbance, it appears that time is moving at a different rate.
It's almost like something shattered the space-time continuum...
The fragmentation effect increases along a heading of two-seven-zero mark one-five.
That's the direction of the Enterprise.
Can we navigate around these... "fragments"?
We'll have to limit our maneuvering speed to one half impulse... but I think we can do it.
Get us to the Enterprise.
These are the coordinates...
Perhaps they've been delayed...
I've got the long range sensors on maximum, sir. No sign of the Enterprise.
But... I am picking up a faint reading... possibly metallic, but I can't tell for sure... The energy levels are practically non-existent.
Take us to it.
Aye sir...
The fragmentation effect is increasing...
Slowing to one eighth impulse...
There she is...
My God...
Mister Data... ?
The Enterprise and the Warbird both appear to be trapped within one of the temporal fragments.
The fragments seem to converge at this point... I'd say we're looking at the center of the temporal disturbances.
Scan for life signs.
Sensors cannot penetrate the subspace field. I am unable to scan within the vessels.
It looks like the Enterprise has been damaged... There, on the starboard nacelle...
The Warbird doesn't look damaged at all... I wonder if the Enterprise even got off a shot...
The Romulans could've decloaked before the Enterprise had a chance to respond...
There's a second energy beam. It's coming from the Enterprise deflector array... any idea what it could be?
It is impossible to tell from a visual inspection. But it appears to be focused on the Warbird's Engineering section.
We're not going to figure out what happened from here. We need to get aboard the Enterprise.
That would be unadvisable, sir. In each of the three instances we came into contact with a temporal fragment, we were integrated into its time frame.
If we beamed aboard the Enterprise, we'd be frozen in time, just like they are.
Then we've got to find a way to stay unfrozen...
Mister La Forge... what about a subspace forcefield like the one we used on Devidia Two? Could something like that protect us from the effects of the temporal fragment?
Possibly. But we'd need a pretty sensitive phase discriminator to modulate that kind of field...
The emergency Transporter armbands contain a type-seven phase discriminator. It should be possible to reconfigure their subspace emitters.
Yeah... that would certainly isolate us from the effects of the other time frame...
But if we want to interact with that environment... we'd have to restrict the field. It would have to be practically skin-tight.
I will attempt to narrow the field.
This might work, Captain. But it's going to take some time...
It would seem that time is one thing we have plenty of...
I've channeled communications through the subspace relays in the armbands. We'll be in continual contact.
How long will the fields last?
An hour, maybe less. Don't worry. I'll monitor you very carefully...
Is there something wrong, Counselor?
I got a little dizzy there for a second...
We're generating an artificial pocket of time around you -- it's probably playing tricks on your equilibrium... It might take a little while to get used to. Let me know if it gets any worse.
Beam us directly to the Enterprise Bridge.
Aye sir.
Energizing...
Three Romulans... all armed with disruptors... one at Conn... There are none of our security officers on the Bridge. They must've taken us by surprise....
It would appear that we can move objects in this time frame.
Maybe we can do something to help Wil...
I'm wary about making changes in this time continuum until we understand more about what's going on.
None of the equipment is functioning. However, the information currently displayed indicates that there was a massive power surge in Engineering.
Security teams had just been sent to Transporter Room Three... and Sickbay.
Counselor -- you go to Sickbay. Have a look around. Data, go to Main Engineering -- see if you can determine the cause of the power surge. I'll be in Transporter Room Three. Picard to La Forge.
La Forge here, sir.
Lock onto our signals. I want you to beam Counselor Troi to --
I'd rather not, Captain. We've got limited power... and your isolation fields consume a lot of energy.
Understood. We'll use the Jefferies Tubes. Let's go.
T-Sixteen is directly ahead -- it's the main junction for this section of the ship. We should have reasonably easy access to our destinations from there...
Maybe we can get around them...
No. We'll find an alternate route. Let's go back up.
Excuse me, Mister Worf...
Captain...
Counselor. Take a look at this...
It appears that Mister Worf had just beamed these three aboard...
According to this, three other Romulans were beamed directly to Sickbay just seconds before.
I know. I just saw them...
Why would we be transporting Romulans onto our ship in the middle of a battle?
They don't have any weapons... and that one looks injured. If they were part of an invasion, why are they unarmed? It doesn't make sense...
Captain... there's something I have to tell you... Doctor Crusher has been hit by a disruptor blast at point blank range... if time returns to normal, I don't see how she can survive.
There must be something we can do...
Data to Captain Picard.
Picard here.
Please come to Engineering immediately. It is urgent.
What's the problem, Mister Data?
I believe I have discovered the cause of the power surge. There is a warp core breach in progress.
It is the flashpoint of a warp core explosion. And it is expanding.
Expanding... I thought time was suspended on this ship.
We were incorrect. I have determined that time is moving forward at an infinitesimal rate.
Why didn't we notice it before?
Our initial conclusion was based on our observations of the crew. A warp core breach moves at a much faster rate.
The motion of the cloud is within my visual detection threshold. Based on its current expansion rate, it will consume the ship in approximately nine hours, seventeen minutes.
Is there any way we can stop it?
It is no longer a question of stopping it, sir. The explosion has already occurred -- The fact that it is moving slowly changes nothing.
Astonishing... to see it frozen like this...
Do we know what caused the breach?

No. However, the console displays indicate that there was a power transfer in progress from the Enterprise to the Romulan vessel at the moment time decelerated. That is why there is a second beam between the two ships.
Why would we be sending them power?
Perhaps we should go aboard the Romulan ship. The answer to that question may --
Captain?
Captain, what's wrong?
My head... dizzy... I can't...
No!
Troi to La Forge. Get us out of here, now!
It looks like you weren't completely protected from the effects of the other time continuum... The neuro-physical stress must've been overwhelming.
In much the same way that deep sea divers can experience nitrogen narcosis -- you experienced a form of temporal narcosis.
Can we modify the subspace isolators to give us better protection?

I don't think so. All we can do right now is be careful -- limit our exposure to their time frame. We probably shouldn't stay any longer than ten minutes per trip. And we should stick together while we're there... just in case.

Very well. Our next step is to find out why the Enterprise was transferring power to the Romulan ship. We'll begin our search in their engine room. Counselor -- you spent several days on a Romulan ship -- you know more about their lay-outs than anyone here. Perhaps you can --
Captain. It might be better if you stayed here this time and gave yourself a chance to recover.
You're right... I'll monitor your progress from here. Ten minutes... no more.
